In the [[Hebrew Bible]], wisdom is represented by [[Solomon]], who asks God for wisdom in {{bibleref2|2 Chronicles|1:10}}. Much of the [[Book of Proverbs]], a book of [[Proverb|wise sayings]], is attributed to Solomon. In {{bibleref2|Proverbs|9:10}} the fear of [[YHWH]] is called the beginning of wisdom. In {{bibleref2|Proverbs|1:20}} there is also reference to wisdom personified in female form, "Wisdom calls aloud in the streets, she raises her voice in the marketplaces." In {{bibleref2|Proverbs|8:22–31}} this personified wisdom is described as being present with God before creation began and even taking part in creation itself.
−   −
Here are some of the roles that the Hebrew Bible ascribes to wisdom:
  −
:Building and establishing civilization ({{bibleref2|Proverbs|24:3–4}}).
  −
:Elevating life ({{bibleref2|Proverbs|3:21-23}}).
  −
:Safety and avoiding misery ({{bibleref2|Proverbs|3:21–23}}).
  −
:Exceeding the value of gold and silver ({{bibleref2|Proverbs|16:16}}).
  −
:Giver of patience and glory ({{bibleref2|Proverbs|19:11}}).
  −
:She (Wisdom) is the primal architect of creation who existed with God before the universe was formed ({{bibleref2|Proverbs|8:30}})<ref name="Hebrew = 'amown">[http://scripturetext.com/proverbs/8-30.htm "master workman", Hebrew]</ref>
       
The [[Talmud]] teaches that a wise person is a person who can foresee the future. ''Nolad'' is the Hebrew word for "future," but also the Hebrew word for ''birth'', so one rabbinic interpretation of the teaching is that a wise person is one who can foresee the consequences of his/her choices (i.e. can "see the future" that he/she "gives birth" to).<ref>[[David Wolpe|Wolpe, David]], perf. [http://sinaitemple.org/learning_with_the_rabbis/sermons/mp3/2012/Sermon081812.mp3 "Re'eh: What it Means to Choose."] ''Rabbi David Wolpe''. Sinai Temple, 11 Aug 2012. web. 16 Aug 2013.</ref>
